info.headline: Flood Advisory issued March 24 at 1:07AM EDT until March 25 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 1245 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...Southern Caldwell and northeast Burke counties in North Carolina. * WHEN...Until 1245 PM EDT Thursday. * IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas including farmland, nurseries, woodlands, low-water crossings, and boat-access areas is expected. Nuisance flooding is defined as less than 2` inundation of farmland, nurseries, woodlands. parks, greenways, boat-access area, and low-water crossings and less than 1` inundation of secondary roads. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1257 AM EDT, Although rainfall has ended across Burke and Caldwell counties, periods of moderate to heavy rain over the past 12 hours resulted in storm-total accumulations of 2-4 inches across the area. This caused within-bank rises on most streams across Burke and Caldwell counties; however, high flows within the Wilson Creek, Mulberry Creek, and Johns River headwaters caused earlier nuisance flooding near Collettsville and Old Johns River Rd and the small floodwave is now traveling downstream of Collettsville into Burke County and the Chesterfield community. This will cause nuisance flooding along the Johns River from the Adako community to the NC 18/US 64 boat-access area. Johns River at Corpening Bridge Rd is currently at 7.46 feet and is rising rapidly. Johns River is expected to exceed Action/Advisory Stage of 8.5 feet over the next 1-2 hours with a crest near 10 feet possible into the early morning hours. A reasonable worst-case crest of 11 feet is possible. Between 9.0 and 10.0 feet: Playmore Beach Rd, Johns River Rd, and other low-water crossings along Johns River begin to flood. Between 10.5 and 11.5 feet: The boat-access area and parking lot at NC 18/US 64 begins to flood. Additionally, high flows along tributaries feeding Lake Rhodhiss is causing a rapid pool rise. The pool at Lake Rhodhiss is at 100.4 feet and may continue to rise past 101.0 feet overnight tonight and early this morning. Nuisance flooding along the lake shoreline including of docks and some residential yards is possible if the lake exceeds 101.0 feet. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Morganton, Longview, Sawmills, Granite Falls, Valdese, Drexel, Connelly Springs, Rutherford College, Rhodhiss, Lake Rhodhiss, Lake Hickory, Collettsville and Northlakes.
info.instruction: When it is safe to do so, please report flooding or landslides threatening roads or property to the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message should describe the specific location where impacts occurred and the depth of flooding observed.
